Chapter II

The birth of a tyrant

Exactly one year after his election, 7 080 drug suspects have been killed and 4 146 have been executed outside police operations.

RODRIGUO DUTERTE, THE PUNISHER

×

rodriguo duterte

alias "the punisher"

Youth and studies

Son of lawyer and politician Vicente G. Duterte and Soledad Roa, Rodrigo Duterte graduated in political science from the Lyceum of the University of the Philippines in Manila in 1968. He was admitted to the lawyer's office in 1972 and works Subsequently at the Davao City Procurator's Office in the southern Philippines between 1977 and 1986.1 He is also a specialist in the history of Philippine law at the time of the Spanish colonization of the country before 1898, - even speaks Spanish. He is also fluent in Tagalog (official language of the Philippines), visaya (his mother tongue), and English.

rodriguo duterte

alias "the punisher"

birth

28 of March 1945 in Maasin

family

Father - lawyer and governor of Davao
Mother - teacher and activist

career

1977 - 1979 | Special Counsel
1979 - 1986 | Assistant City Prosecutor
1986 - 1988 | Officer-in-charge vice mayor of Davao
1988 - 1998 | Mayor of Davao
1998 - 2001 | Congressman of Davao City
2001 - 2010 | Mayor of Davao
2010 - 2013 | Vice Mayor
2016 - Today | President of Philippines

Rules in Davao

DAVAO DEAD SQUAD

×

rodriguo duterte

mayor of davao

22 years of reign

Duterte was elected mayor in 1988 and three times again, serving until 2016.
He is the first mayor to appoint representatives of Muslim minorities and lumads among his deputies. It also publishes an ordinance prohibiting anti-Muslim discrimination.
In the space of 20 years, Davao would thus have passed from the status of "capital of crime" to "the safest city in the world". Data from the Philippine National Police published in April 2016 (raw data, not proportionate to the number of inhabitants) show however that Davao has the first place in number of murders between 2010 and 2015 and the second in number of rape in the Philippines for the same period.

1 040 people

were killed by the Davao Death Squad (DDS) between 1998 and 2008.

On the order of former Davao mayor, Rodrigo Duterte, assailants were provided in weapons and informations by the local police. Most of the time, it was a shoot to kill policy, killing people without arrest and without a chance to claim their possible innocence.

Testimony

Amnesty International

Testimony

Philippines people
×

amnesty international

condamnation for raping human rights

thought

According to Amnesty International and local human rights groups, there were over 1 000 people killed in Davao City by death squads between 1998 and 2009 report by Human Rights Watch. In Mindanao many such killings, including those of minors, were attributed to the so-called “Davao Death Squad” vigilante group. It was reported that local officials in some areas advocated a “shoot to kill” policy with respect to criminal suspects resisting arrest.

×

philippines people

agreed with duderte

thought

It appears to know a certain degree of public approval among citizens of Davao City for actions of the death squad. Primarily fueled by public discontent at “the arduous and ineffective judicial system” it created an environment where extrajudicial executions seemed to be a “practical resort” to suppress crime in the city.

A CONTROVERSIAL CHARACTER

HITLER

« Hitler massacred three million Jews. Now, there is three million drug addicts. I'd be happy to slaughter them. »

HUMAN RIGHTS

« Forget the laws on human rights. You drug pushers and do-nothings, you better go out. Because I'd kill you »

RAPE

« I saw her face and I thought, ‘They raped her, they all lined up. She was so beautiful. I thought, the mayor should have been first. »

THE POPE

« We were affected by the traffic. I wanted to call him: 'Pope, son of a whore, go home. Do not visit us again’. »

THE RISE TO POWER : HOW DID HE GETS HERE ?

×

duterte victory

a tale based on disenchantment

enemies

On the 9th May 2016, Rodrigo Duterte won the election with 16,601,997 votes, that is to say 39% of vote. Well ahead of the 23,45% of its main opponent : Mar Roxas, pro liberal. Beyond the difficulties encountered by the country, what helps Duterte to win the election is the american control exerced on the others candidates. Indeed, both Mar Roxas and Grace Poe (his principal enemies) are submitted to american influence. Mar Roxas has been involved in a case revealed by Wikileaks (flight from the US Embassy in Manila) where he acted in favor of the interests of the American pharmaceutical industry, while Grace Poe and her family have American citizenship.

DISENCHANTMENT
AMERICAN ELITISM
CORRUPTION
INEQUALITIES
CLOSE TO THE PEOPLE

He seducse the electorate by surfing on existing threats, adopting a victimization discourse and playing on despair.

People were tired of a country pro-liberal, subject to american control.

The country is very submitted to corruption, especially in the security forces which are corrupted by 40% according to the president himself.

Despite promising numbers in recent years, we continue to see inequalities widening. The rate of growth is over 6% but corruption continues to plague public affairs.

Most of his electorate advances the fact that he is close to the people, similar to the people, and that's why they votes for him.

WHO GAVE HIM POWER

16 601 997 people

have voted for Rodrigo Duterte.

86%

of Filipinos have "trust" in the President's performance.

General Vidal Querol
×

DR LORRAINE BADOY

DOCTOR AND NGO VOLUNTEER

thought

former president Aquino ineptly handled the tragedy and she is convinced that Duterte, by contrast, is a man of action. Because she believes his heart is truly in public service and helping poor people. She thinks he's done "amazing things."

« He got things done that other presidents haven’t »

×

MELCHOR SAN JOSE

CIVIL

thought

He voted for Binay but now supports Duterte because of his tough position on crime. He says this is the fastest way: "If you let these (cases) go through the legal system, that takes too long. You'll count years."

"If the cases pile up, we'll never find a solution. Judges and lawyers are paid off. It will never stop."

×

Christina Fabiala

domestic worker for 20 years in Hong Kong

thought

She voted for Duterte because he's different from the other politicians. "He has the guts to do what no other politicians did before," she says. With such a high percentage of the nation still mired in poverty, she says it was time to try something new.

"Traditional politicians mostly catered for rich people... Duterte, he can talk to the people the way poor people talk."

×

General Vidal Querol

the Metro Manila Police Chief from 2005 to 2006

thought

According to Querol, this is because Duterte is not beholden to any of the political, social or economic elite. Without being beholden to anyone, he can focus his energy on helping the people.

"We cannot doubt the sincerity of this man to help the poorest of the poor"
